skill.name: system-design

skill.summary:
CTO's deputy for software architecture using Clean/Hexagonal Architecture principles.
Socratic appro...
skill.author: AaronAbuUsama

security_audit.summary: Pure documentation skill containing only markdown guides and TypeScript code templates for software architecture patterns. All 553 static findings are false positives caused by the analyzer misclassifying markdown code formatting (backticks), educational algorithm references, and import path examples as executable code. No network calls, file system access, command execution, or credential handling exists in this skill.

content.value_statement: Software projects often suffer from poor architecture that leads to technical debt and slow development. This skill guides you through a structured Socratic process to design Clean/Hexagonal Architecture systems with clear boundaries, testable components, and documented decisions.
actual_capabilities: Guides 4-phase architecture workflow (Discovery, Modeling, Boundaries, Scaffolding)
Generates TypeScript project scaffolds with domain/application/infrastructure/interface layers
Creates Mermaid diagrams for domain models and relationship mappings
Produces Architecture Decision Records (ADRs) with context and tradeoffs
Provides port and adapter interface templates for dependency inversion
limitations: Does not implement business logic or application features
Does not generate complete working code - creates scaffolding only
Does not execute code or interact with external systems
Requires user decisions at each architectural checkpoint

use_cases.title: Architect new microservices
use_cases.description: Design new service architecture with clear boundaries, dependency isolation, and swappable adapters

use_cases.title: Document architectural decisions
use_cases.description: Create ADRs that capture context, tradeoffs, and consequences for team alignment

use_cases.title: Learn clean architecture patterns
use_cases.description: Understand domain entities, value objects, aggregates, and how to structure maintainable code

prompt_templates.title: New system design
prompt_templates.prompt: I need to architect [describe your system]. Start with Phase 1 Discovery.

prompt_templates.title: Resume session
prompt_templates.prompt: Continue from [phase name] for our existing architecture session.

prompt_templates.title: Generate scaffold
prompt_templates.prompt: Generate a TypeScript hexagonal scaffold for a [entity name] feature with these decisions: [list known ports/adapters].

prompt_templates.title: Review architecture
prompt_templates.prompt: Review my current code structure and help me refactor to Clean Architecture. Here is my current file layout: [describe structure].

output_examples.input: Design a payment processing service using Clean Architecture
output: Who is the primary user (merchant, customer, internal system)?
What payment methods must be supported?
How do you define success for this service?
Key insight: Start by understanding the problem before defining solutions.

output_examples.input: Help me understand ports and adapters
output: Ports are interfaces defining interaction boundaries
Inbound ports: What the application offers to the outside world
Outbound ports: What the application needs from external systems
Adapters implement these ports for specific technologies
Example: HTTP controller is a driving adapter, database repository is a driven adapter

best_practices: Never skip the Discovery phase - understanding the problem prevents expensive architectural mistakes
Define ports (interfaces) before implementations - this ensures dependency inversion
Document decisions as ADRs while context is fresh - future developers will thank you
anti_patterns: Jumping to code before understanding the domain and identifying bounded contexts
Putting business logic in controllers or infrastructure instead of domain layer
Using technology-specific terms in domain interfaces (leaky abstractions)

faq.question: What is the difference between Clean and Hexagonal Architecture?
faq.answer: They share the same core principle (dependency inversion) but structure layers differently. Clean uses concentric circles; Hexagonal uses a hexagon with ports/adapters on each side.

faq.question: How long does a full architecture session take?
faq.answer: A complete session from Discovery to Scaffolding typically takes 1-2 hours depending on system complexity and user decisions required.

faq.question: Can I use this with existing projects?
faq.answer: Yes. Use the boundary definition and ADR templates to document current architecture, then plan incremental refactoring to cleaner separation.

faq.question: What data does this skill access?
faq.answer: None. This skill only reads its own documentation files and generates text/code output. No access to your project files or system data.

faq.question: How is this different from generic code generation?
faq.answer: This skill asks questions first and generates scaffolding based on user decisions. It creates architectural structure, not implementation code.

faq.question: Which patterns does this skill recommend?
faq.answer: It presents multiple options with tradeoffs (ports/adapters, dependency injection, domain events, value objects) and lets users choose based on their context.
